We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory, which is independent of any analytical structure. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of interest to both the scientific community and the public because of their extreme reduction in body plan and their potential as a model system for the study of the evolution of parasitism. In this study, we present the first genome assemblies for two species of myxozoans, and we compare these to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the evolution of the Myxozoa was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique resource for the study of the evolution of parasitism and the development of a model system for the study of the evolution of parasitism. (Show more)

Our findings are of great importance for the understanding of the mechanisms of action of SARS-CoV-2 and other viruses that use similar strategies to evade IFN signaling. They also provide a potential target for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1 channels, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, and that this increase will be larger than the increase in mean yields. This increase in variability will have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and for the food security of the world’s poorest people.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food-plant species is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of food plants. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant LMH species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. Our results suggest that, despite their similar body size, LMH partition food-plant species in a manner that is not driven by trophic guild. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH in African savanna biodiversity and for the management of LMH in human-dominated landscapes.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. Our findings suggest that the crisis is already having a large impact on small businesses, with many already laying off workers and closing. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will need to be expanded to provide sufficient funding to support small businesses through the crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System and the evolution of the early solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains.

Reproductive output is limited by the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is limited by the amount of time the mother has to allocate to reproduction, which is limited by the amount of time she has to allocate to other activities. We show that the amount of time a mother has to allocate to reproduction is strongly limited by the amount of time she has to allocate to allonursing her offspring.

This study is an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of multiple system atrophy. This study also demonstrates that VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in the striatum of this mouse model. Finally, this study shows that VX-765 is able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of this mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in patients with MSA. This study is also a proof of concept for the use of prodrugs in the treatment of synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the first line of defense against the entry of pathogens and other harmful substances into the body. It is also the first line of communication between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform a variety of functions. This paper describes the structure of the endothelial network, which is the communication system between the cells. The network is designed to be both local and global in its communication, and to be robust and fast in its response to stimuli.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and open data has never been greater. We have created a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of signals of COVID-19 activity, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available through the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface for accessing the data. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that this data platform will be useful to researchers, policymakers, and the general public.

This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the inactivation gate and the activation gate in K+ channels. This coupling is a key feature of the gating of K+ channels, and it is likely to be present in other ion channels.

This study is the first to investigate the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which are a group of microorganisms that are important members of the gut microbiome. We found that anaerobic fungi synthesize a wide variety of natural products, including antibiotics, peptides, and polyketides. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a promising source of natural products. This study also provides a foundation for future studies that will investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products that could be used in the pharmaceutical, agricultural, and food industries.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the establishment of social hierarchy and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our findings suggest that the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens may be a promising target for the treatment of anxiety-related social disorders.

This work is about the design of mechanical structures that can exhibit any desired response under large deformation. The design is based on the synthesis of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are then fabricated into mechanical devices. The devices exhibit a wide range of responses, including complex shapes and motions, and can be navigated by external stimuli. The proposed design strategy can be extended to other fields, such as architecture, engineering, and biology.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of the blood. It is synthesized in the nucleus of the red blood cell (RBC) and is expressed in a developmental pattern that is determined by the age of the RBC. This developmental pattern is important for the delivery of oxygen to the tissues. In this study, we show that the protein IGF2BP1, which is involved in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway, is expressed in the nucleus of the RBC and is involved in the developmental pattern of hemoglobin.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is regulated by a variety of mechanisms. In this study, we found that the cell cycle is regulated by the mTORC1 pathway, which is activated by mutations in the PI3K-AKT pathway. We also found that the mTORC1 pathway is activated by mutations in the PI3K-AKT pathway, and that this activation is required for the survival of cancer cells.

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and it is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular medicine. However, despite the availability of multiple classes of antihypertensive drugs, the majority of patients do not achieve the desired blood pressure control. This is due to the development of drug resistance, which is associated with the remodeling of the vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs). In this study, we identified a mechanism of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers, which promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension and cardiovascular diseases.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the declines of older-forest–associated species accelerated. Our findings suggest that the NWFP has not yet had time to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems on federal land may have the opposite effect, as it may reduce the development of older-forest structures. Our results highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the rational design of new antibiotics. View Full-Text

We introduce a new architecture for deep learning that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that this architecture will be useful for many applications in computer vision and image processing.

This paper presents a 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the tropics, which is one of the most important controls on the evolution of the biosphere. We show that the evolution of the climate system is not a gradual process, but rather is punctuated by abrupt changes in the environment. These changes are driven by changes in the orbital forcing of the climate system, but are also influenced by changes in the internal dynamics of the climate system.

This study shows that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. The results suggest that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime may have a negative impact on sleep, performance, and health.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the last deglaciation of the last ice age. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Os in the YDB samples is likely terrestrial in origin, and that the source of the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules is in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, 1.5 Ga old.

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for the induction of autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the history of this order remains poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes to date to resolve the evolutionary history of this group. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including those used in vaccines and therapeutics. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We find that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. Instead, we find that the size of the population may actually have a negative effect on cumulative cultural evolution.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We have found that APOE is important for the normal function of astrocytes, which is to remove synapses that are no longer functional. APOE is also important for the normal rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We propose that the APOE4 allele may increase AD risk by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 increases the accumulation of a protein that is part of the classical complement pathway in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the size of a small country. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is the last part of the Earth to solidify, and its formation is a mystery. We show that the inner core formed by a two-step process, which is the first time that such a mechanism has been proposed.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain DA responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are reduced in marijuana abusers. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world are also the most predictive, and that this predictive power is strongly correlated with the accuracy of the models on a language comprehension task. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to the nature of the problem or the nature of the algorithm. We study this question by focusing on the stability of neural networks (NNs), which are the basic building blocks of DL. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable NNs, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, and we explain it by showing that the stability of NNs is not a property of the algorithm, but rather a property of the problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. In 1975, a classic experiment was published that has been cited more than 1,000 times. However, its design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon it set out to study. Here, we discuss the flaws of the study and its implications for the field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a rare reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they have been able to adapt to their respective host environments, and that they are still able to cause disease.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources in quantum information science and the two main ingredients in the formulation of thermodynamics. However, the evolution of entanglement and entropy is different in general, and the interplay between them is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit is completely determined by the steady state and its excitations. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical data.

This study describes the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a segment of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, resulting in a large number of silent mutations. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is highly protective in hamsters, and the protective effect is maintained in the presence of neutralizing antibodies. This study provides a proof of concept for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which can be used in mass vaccination programs. This study also provides a platform for the development of other live attenuated vaccines against other viruses. (Show more)

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the development of modern medicine. In this study, we developed a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results also suggest that the spread of plague in Europe was not only driven by the Black Death, but also by other outbreaks. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to improve the control of plague today.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of comparative neuroethology. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which are the basic units of information processing, has been largely ignored. This study fills this gap by using the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of neuron numbers across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This study also shows that the evolution of brain size is not only associated with the evolution of brain mass but also with the evolution of brain numbers. These results have important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have found that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor by promoting a metabolic switch that favors the use of fatty acids for energy production. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These findings may lead to the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamics of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the actin network. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a sugar found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for the role of fructose in the development of obesity and the role of brain reward processing in the regulation of food intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the genetic history of the island in a fine-scale. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions, which is the result of a complex history of colonization and admixture. Our results suggest that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event, but rather a series of independent colonizations from Africa and Asia. In addition, we show that the genetic structure of the island is already detectable after a few centuries. This is a first step toward a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar. We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is the first experimental evidence of emotional contagion in a large-scale social network. Our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact in person. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. Finally, our results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they do not interact in person.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation, and the presence of chemical modifications in coding regions can have profound effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have a modest impact on protein synthesis, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in a manner that can alter protein synthesis. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. This finding has implications for the development of interventions to promote healthy aging.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major human pathogen that causes a variety of diseases, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and sepsis. This opportunistic pathogen is also responsible for chronic infections in the cystic fibrosis lung, where it forms a biofilm that is difficult to eradicate. In this study, we show that P. aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to detect the presence of surfaces, and that this signal is used to regulate the expression of virulence factors. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of this important pathogen and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of chronic infections. (Show more)

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that, although the number of monitored sites is still very low, the risk of pesticide contamination of surface waters is substantial. This risk is likely to increase in the future, as the number of monitored sites is expected to increase, and the number of new-generation pesticides is expected to be released.

This study is the first to document the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. The findings suggest that deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection and may play a role in the ongoing pandemic. Our results also highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, including the role of animals in the transmission of the virus. This study provides a foundation for future research on the role of animals in the pandemic and the development of a “One Health” approach to monitoring and mitigating the spread of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is not being addressed. This paper examines the problems associated with the construction of large dams in the developing world, including the impacts on the environment, people, and food systems. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of extensive research. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are also involved in the AD pathogenesis. We demonstrate that neurons are the source of an inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric Aβ in the brain may be the main cause of the neuroinflammation, which is a key feature of AD.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most controversial. The present study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken by showing that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is found in the ancient city of Maresha, Israel. This evidence, which dates to the fourth–second centuries B.C.E., is based on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. The results of our survey of chicken remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, show a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken and on the process of its integration into the local economy. It also sheds light on the process of the spread of the chicken in the ancient world. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are thought to be alarmones, are alarmones in bacteria. They are thought to be precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are thought to be caps in bacteria. We show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is thought to be the decapping enzyme in bacteria, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped transcripts. This enzyme, which is thought to be the sole decapping enzyme in bacteria, is not the enzyme that is thought to be responsible for decapping other capped transcripts.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although there are several treatments for sepsis, there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of arginine in the immune system and its possible involvement in the pathogenesis of sepsis. View Full-Text

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass composition.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. We also show that the model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including photonics, electronics, and quantum technologies. However, diamond is also a material with a high risk of phonon instability under mechanical strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, through strain engineering, to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

This work is about the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are derived from the model legume Medicago truncatula. These peptides are highly diverse in sequence, and some of them exhibit potent antifungal activity in vitro and in vivo. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, which are derived from the model legume Medicago truncatula. We also report the solution of the NMR structure of one of the peptides, which is highly dynamic and has a unique structure. This work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The female reproductive tract is a complex environment that interacts with sperm during the entire life cycle of the sperm. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the normal function of platelets. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We have developed a method to measure the force-dependent conformational changes in VWF. We find that the A1 domain of VWF is in a second state at low force, which is the active state for binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is the focus of intense study. The viral component of the microbiome has been a more challenging target than the bacteriome, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. This study fills this gap, and provides a resource for future studies of the human virome. We find that many of the strongest associations between viruses and disease are with viruses that have been previously identified, but that many others are novel. We also find that the virome is more complex than the bacteriome, and that the human microbiome is likely to be a complex system.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can simultaneously measure aerosol and water cloud properties. This technique is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. Here, we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over time, in agreement with other methods of determining the temperature of the early Earth.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the heart. Ion channels are also the targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are also the targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are the targets of drugs and toxins.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 209 million cases and 465,000 deaths in 2017. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs and vector control, there is still no cure for malaria. The malaria parasite, Plasmodium, is able to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may facilitate invasion. This finding would suggest that the malaria parasite is not just a parasite, but also a physical force, working in concert with the RBC, to cause disease.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for a wide range of applications, including photonics, electronics, and quantum devices. However, diamond is also a material with a high risk of phonon instability under mechanical strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, through strain engineering, to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. We show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe influenza disease, and that this effect is independent of viral burden. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Finally, we demonstrate that low humidity reduces the induction of IFN-stimulated genes in the lung, and that this effect is caspase-1/11 dependent. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which low humidity contributes to influenza disease severity. Our results also suggest that dampers of the immune response, such as caspase-1/11, may be potential targets for the development of influenza vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s activity during the construction of such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity varies with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly when words can be merged into a phrase. Our results suggest that the brain performs a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More generally, our findings provide evidence for a neural implementation of a left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. They also suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Vertebrates have two forms of Axin, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a unique insight into the regulation of redundant genes and may be of interest to the general public.

This work is a continuation of our previous studies on the lateral hypothalamus and its role in the regulation of food intake. We have shown that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus can induce eating in the absence of satiety. In this study, we have identified a critical circuit that may be involved in the development of obesity.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the functioning of the world’s ecosystems and is of great importance to agriculture. However, the use of free-living nitrogen-fixing bacteria as a nitrogen source in agriculture is limited by the lack of a sustainable way to deliver the bacteria to the roots of the desired host plant. Here, we demonstrate the development of a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria’s ability to fix nitrogen in response to the host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of symbiosis.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by increasing the speed at which deforestation alerts reach communities and by providing training and incentives for community members to respond to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,00

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

This work is a proof of concept for a strategy to rapidly develop a subunit vaccine for SARS-CoV-2 that can be manufactured at large scale and at low cost. The engineered RBD is a promising candidate for inclusion in a vaccine, and the VLP platform is a well-established vaccine technology. This work provides a framework for the rapid development of vaccines for other emerging viruses.

We show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vivo. This finding is of importance for the understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence is one of the most important events in the history of medicine. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during the formative years, from the origins of Yersinia pestis to its adaptation to the flea. Our results suggest that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting for millennia. This lineage underwent a stepwise process of gene loss, which may have been important in the adaptation of plague to the flea. Our findings provide insights into the origins of plague and its early evolution, which will be useful for understanding the history of this disease and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM in the United States and beyond.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols has led to massive C losses to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not increase mineral-associated SOC, which is the most stable form of soil C. These results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial grasslands into annual cropping systems to mitigate climate change.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses is publicly available in an interactive web tool, SpillOver, which can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a first step in a systematic process to identify and prioritize targets for research and public health interventions.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. In this study, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the three enzymatic activities that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

We present a case study of the use of genome-wide data to study the genetic history of a specific population during a specific period. We show that the analysis of the genetic landscape of a specific population at a specific time can provide insights into the processes that shaped it. In addition, we demonstrate the utility of functional variants to study the genetic history of a specific population at a specific time.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. Our results suggest that the receptor usage and host range of the spike protein are important determinants for the cross-species transmission of bat coronaviruses. These results also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

This study is a proof of concept for a new approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response.

This work is a continuation of our previous work on the structure and function of the human pol δ holoenzyme. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We have found that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as stable as the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme and that the human pol δ holoenzyme is not as processive as the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme. These results have important implications for the structure and function of the human pol δ holoenzyme.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In this work, we show that RNA can replicate itself, and that the resulting RNA polymerase can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work is a major step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world, and it provides a platform for the study of the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our results will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage, and the treatment effect is still not satisfactory. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is effective in rheumatoid arthritis, may be effective in the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is poorly understood. Here we demonstrate that the xanthocillin-producing fungus Aspergillus fumigatus has a mechanism for sensing and responding to copper. We show that the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) is expressed in response to copper, and that the BGC-derived isocyanide products bind copper and impact cellular copper content. We also show that xanthocillin-treated Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth is remediated by copper. These results suggest that the xanthocillin BGC is involved in sensing and responding to copper, and that the BGC-derived isocyanide products may be involved in mediating interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungi in copper homeostasis and the potential for fungal natural products to mediate interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature SiO2 polymorph, in a sedimentary mudstone at the surface of Mars is a surprising discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit is consistent with the presence of a silicic volcanic source, and the timing of its formation is consistent with the formation of the deposit.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors that affect the growth and survival of plants and animals. In the last decades, the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) has increased in many regions of the Northern Hemisphere, with potentially severe consequences for agriculture, forestry, and wildlife. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the innate strategies of trees for minimizing frost damage to their leaves. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management, forestry, and agricultural practices to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis. Our findings may have implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We have developed a method to rapidly and easily produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and identify potential therapeutics. This method will also enable the rapid production of motor neuron-like cells for clinical trials. This will help to accelerate the development of therapies for ALS.

This study provides a unique example of a human pathogen exploiting an arthropod protein to alter the microbiota of its vector. This work also provides a model for understanding the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector.
This paper describes a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that the water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is because the water vapor in the stratosphere is very dry, and therefore it is very sensitive to changes in temperature.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we describe a new mechanism that allows animals to change color, and we show that this mechanism has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. The development of breast cancer is associated with the presence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, which is a m6A demethylase, and that ALKBH5 expression is required for the maintenance of CSCs. Our findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment is not supported by the data.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle underwent a major reorganization immediately preceding the extinction, and carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. They also provide a basis for a more refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that is involved in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides insights into the function of RORα in the intestine and suggests that therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in the closed and in the open conformation. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has a dramatic effect on the conformational dynamics of the receptor-binding domain. The open conformation of the spike protein is associated with a more efficient binding to the receptor, ACE2. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, for a large class of games, there exists an equilibrium in which each player plays a fixed strategy, regardless of the history of the game. This result is obtained by combining techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

We show that the chemical properties of atoms, which are the most fundamental properties of chemistry, change with pressure. We show that the chemical properties of atoms are the key to understanding the chemical behavior of elements under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the effects of this on the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the effects of climate change on fire activity, and that this can have a significant impact on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that, in some regions, fire activity may be able to offset some of the warming caused by human activities. However, the risk of more extreme fires and the implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems must also be considered.

This work is about the symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. The squid provides the symbiont with a glycan, which is the only nutrient the symbiont can use to survive. The glycan is released by the squid’s immune cells, which migrate into the symbiotic organ just before dusk. We show that the glycan is provided in a cyclic manner, and that the squid’s immune cells migrate into the organ only at night. We also show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiosis. Finally, we show that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which enhances the symbiont’s capacity to produce light at night. This work suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their symbiotic communities.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe, after which it spread over the continent. Our study shows that this assumption is not supported by the available evidence. We find that the plague bacterium was repeatedly introduced into Europe from Asia, and that the time between the first introduction and the establishment of the disease in Europe varied between 15 and 25 y. Our results suggest that the establishment of the plague in Europe was the result of multiple introductions of the bacterium, rather than a single introduction.

Asteroid species are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for a variety of predators. They are also a source of food for humans. In the last 2 y, a disease has caused the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with the rapid degradation of the animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We have identified a target for treatment of AML, IL1RAP, and have developed an antibody that can target this protein. This antibody has the potential to be used in the treatment of AML, and it may also be useful in the treatment of other diseases in which IL1RAP is important.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the genetic history of Madagascar in a fine-scale. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, which are the result of a complex history. Our results suggest that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher probability of settlement by males. In addition, we find that the genetic structure of the island is the result of a combination of the settlement history and the geographic distribution of the genetic diversity. This study provides a better understanding of the human history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. View Full-Text

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including vaccines and other therapeutics. Our work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the development of vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in the United States. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is conducted by the US Department of Agriculture, can be used to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC survey is a valuable source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert assessments in quantitative analyses, and can be extended to other countries and crops.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information in the brain. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to store information about the past and the future. This mechanism is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of a small number of neurons. These changes are driven by the dynamics of the membrane potential and are not dependent on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that may be useful for understanding the neural basis of language in the future.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to scientists and policymakers. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Our analysis of the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results suggest that soil respiration may not be as responsive to warming as previously thought, and that the response of soil respiration to climate change may be highly variable across the globe.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is not the only driver of the evolution of the plastid genome, and that the loss of function is not always linked to the loss of function.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is one of the most severe in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is likely to be even larger in the future, as the probability of multiyear droughts will increase by a factor of two to three by the end of the century. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, is a story of the power of science to reveal the past and the potential of science to shape the future.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are essential for the capture of solar energy. (Bacterio)chlorophylls are the most abundant light-harvesting pigments on Earth, and their biosynthesis is among the most productive biological pathways on the planet. This work identifies three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS). However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS are not fully understood. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the progression of EAE, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes reduced the severity of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not yet fully understood. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results suggest that behavioral inflexibility is a common feature of autism-risk genes and that the ability to forget is a critical component of behavioral flexibility. These findings may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. In the process, it offers a unique contribution to the literature on the psychology of news consumption.

We report on a group of patients with a new syndrome, Stormorken syndrome, which is characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. We show that the mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 that are associated with this syndrome are gain-of-function mutations, and that the mutations in STIM1 are associated with bleeding diathesis and thrombocytopenia. Our findings suggest that the CRAC channel is a therapeutic target for the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome.

We have developed a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease that allows us to study the spreading of aggregates in a defined subset of neurons. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. These findings may help to develop a better understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and may lead to the development of new antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the conversion of serine to glycine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that performs this conversion, and have shown that it is a promising target for cancer therapy. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of one of the most aggressive types of cancer, and have identified a potential therapeutic target for it.
