We observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We expect that the device will be useful for a wide range of applications in quantum optics, quantum simulation, and quantum metrology. Montsechia is a plant that lived and reproduced in the water, similar to Ceratophyllum, but it is much older than Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm, and it is the first plant to be found in the water at a time when the first flowering plants were just emerging from the ground.

Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that has been associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the effects of climate change. This finding is important because it provides a more precise estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is used in many applications, including coastal planning and protection, and in the assessment of the impacts of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction intermediate is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the rate and selectivity of the reaction. NMR-assisted crystallography is a powerful tool for the study of reaction intermediates, and it is used here to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in the context of a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. It also provides a rationale for the use of remdesivir in other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This work is about the symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. The squid provides the symbiont with a glycan, which is the only nutrient that the symbiont can use to survive. The glycan is released by the squid’s immune cells, which migrate into the symbiotic organ just before dusk. We show that the glycan is provided in a cyclic manner, and that the squid’s immune cells migrate into the organ only at night. We also show that the glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the persistence of the symbiosis. Finally, we show that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which enhances the symbiont’s capacity to produce light at night. This work suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their symbiotic communities.

This work is about the importance of relationships in schools. It is also about the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. In the United States, students are suspended from school at a rate of 1 in 10. This work shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a major impact on students’ lives. It also shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline are shaped by the relationships they have with students. This work is about the importance of relationships in schools. DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is involved in the development of cancer and other diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylated DNA lesions on the transcriptional fidelity checkpoints and the transcriptional lesion bypass routes. Our results provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the spike (S) glycoprotein. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40%. This increase in vegetarian meals is sustained over time, and it is not accompanied by a decrease in overall meal sales. These results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could be a simple and effective way to improve population health and the environment. The results also suggest that it may be possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings without compromising overall sales. This study provides evidence that nudging meal selection may be a promising approach for improving population health and the environment.

We have developed a method to measure the surface proteome of cells, and applied it to study the effects of oncogenes on the cell surface proteome. We find that the surfaceome is a dynamic and complex system that is remodeled by oncogenes, and that the effects of oncogenes on the surfaceome are similar to those on the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be useful for the study of cancer and other diseases.

Vote-by-mail has been a popular policy proposal in the United States in recent years, and many scholars and policy makers are urging the country to expand vote-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process in response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

SARS-CoV-2 is the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. It has a number of features that make it more infectious and more severe than the viruses that preceded it. One of these features is the presence of a protein, ORF8, that has not been seen in other coronaviruses. In this paper, we describe the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, and show that it forms a unique large-scale assembly. We discuss how this assembly may be important for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. We also discuss the implications of this work for the development of vaccines and treatments. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a life-threatening condition, and the mechanisms of its development are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes, CRF, acting through CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, and that the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. Finally, using CHO cells transfected with CRFR1+ and AQP4+, we show that transfected CRFR1+ contributes to edema via transfected AQP4+. We live in an era of big data and complex statistical modeling. The size of the data sets and the sophistication of the statistical models make it difficult to assess the significance of the results. We describe a new approach to this problem, which we call selective inference. The idea is that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We illustrate the approach using forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We believe that selective inference will become an important part of the statistical toolkit in the future.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human skin fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, ETVECs can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. We have identified a family of ligands for the receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We have shown that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized epidermal tissue that is present in the eyes and the skin of most vertebrates. This work provides a unique example of a ligand-receptor pair that is essential for the development of a specific tissue.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin secretion, which is essential for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight segments of single-stranded RNA, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral RNA is essential for the production of infectious viruses, but the molecular details of this process are unknown. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of viral RNA segments that are in close contact with each other. This mechanism is sequence dependent and involves a network of interactions between the viral RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral packaging and might help to understand the evolution of influenza A viruses. They also suggest that the packaging of viral RNA segments might be a promising target for antiviral drug development. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in the vascular endothelium. In this study, we identified a critical role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a major cause of economic and ecological damage. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in other countries and other time periods. We hope that our results will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. The model is used to estimate the parameters of the model, which are then used to assess the effect of an antiviral treatment. The model is also used to assess the effect of a potential vaccine. The results of the analysis are used to inform the development of a vaccine and treatment strategy.

Coral bleaching is a key indicator of the health of coral reefs and a major threat to their survival. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are not fully understood. Here, we show that the metabolic and nutritional interactions between coral and symbionts are altered during heat stress, leading to a shift from symbiont growth to their degradation. These processes are a key driver of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help explain the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate a JNK-dependent feedback loop with the microbiome. This loop leads to the loss of the intestinal barrier, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome, and, ultimately, to tumor growth. Our results identify a mechanism that is important for the maintenance of the intestinal barrier and host–microbe homeostasis. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between tumorigenesis and homeostasis of the intestinal epithelium. It also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response of patients to this treatment is highly variable. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still debated. Here we show that the start of the volcanic eruption series is coincident with a unique, 192-y series of halogens in ice cores from Antarctica and the Arctic, which is unprecedented in the last 10,000 y. Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning, and to identify regions where fisheries are most likely to be sustainable and productive.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is delivered as the negative electrode material, which can deliver a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. Furthermore, a full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. We report the discovery of a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting calcium channels and elevating cAMP. We also show that this form of regeneration is a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of a cell is mixed up, and it is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in all organisms. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state of the brain is a complex process that is not fully understood. In this work, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify the resting organization of the brain. We found that the resting state of the brain is organized in networks, and that these networks are altered in disease. This work provides a new perspective on the resting state of the brain and its relationship with disease.

We have identified a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is unique to NAD-modified transcripts. This cap structure is found on a subset of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on transcripts that are 5′ end processed. This cap structure may be important for the stability and/or translation of NAD-modified transcripts.

We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist during the long-term follow-up of people with diabetes, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the DCCT on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up.
This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the brain and is associated with a high risk of relapse. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, and that some of these changes are associated with the development of gut leakiness, which may be important in the development of relapse. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in plants. It also provides a model for the development of a new class of plant-derived flavor compounds.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the impacts of temperature change on this relationship are mediated by changes in species interactions. Our results have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for the formation of spatial representations. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a miniaturized, portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. Our data show that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells, and that grid cells are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a detailed description of the organization of the MEC and its subregions, which will be useful for future studies of the formation of spatial representations. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is the most common movement disorder, and the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra are the primary target of the disease. We show that the dopamine neurons of the substantia nigra are connected to a specialized system within the striatum, which is likely to be critical to the control of movement and motivation.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for the generation of the electrical impulse that propagates through the heart. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of the heartbeat, and their function is critical for the normal functioning of the heart. In this study, we show that the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 is essential for the function of SAN cells and is required for the normal generation of the heartbeat. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivory has not been explored. In this study, we show that Si and jasmonate (JA) interact in mediating resistance against the rice leaffolder. Our results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses may be a key mechanism for the promotion of insect herbivore resistance. This study provides insights into the potential of Si as a sustainable agricultural practice for insect pest management. (Show more)

This work is about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It is about the importance of the enzyme alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism. It is about the importance of the lipidome in the regulation of immune responses.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information in the brain. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to store information about the past and the future. This mechanism is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of a small number of neurons. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

This work is a systematic assessment of the internalization and gene silencing efficiency of DNA nanostructures in plants. We show that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is one of the most pervasive threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of the nutrients that enter lakes and rivers come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in monitoring and regulatory efforts. We show that small tributaries can be important sources of nutrients to coastal areas, where they can fuel algal blooms. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small watersheds, which can be cost-effective and ecologically beneficial. Our results also highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the sources and sinks of nutrients in large water bodies, which are increasingly important for human water supply, recreation, and ecosystem services.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is capable of providing work only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a strong tendency to concentrate in states with a fine-tuned extremization of the external potential. We propose that this phenomenon is a general feature of systems that are forced to absorb work from an environment that is difficult to access.

We show that the effects of NMDAR-Abs on the brain are not limited to the synapse, but extend to the level of the network. This is a major advance in our understanding of the mechanisms of this disease, and may lead to new therapeutic approaches.

This study provides a new perspective on the history of C and U isotope excursions and their potential drivers. We show that the 304 Ma C and U isotope excursions are linked to a global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. Our study also provides a new perspective on the role of organic matter in the Earth system and the potential for organic matter to be a key driver of climate change.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that certification has little impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, and that certification has not yet had a large impact on forest loss in Indonesia. We also show that certification has little impact on deforestation in the first place, because most oil palm plantations are too small to have a large impact on deforestation.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of the endocytic vesicles to the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of the exocytosis process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of animals, and the mechanisms that determine sex are the focus of intense study. In this work, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual polymorphism, where the same trait can be sexually dimorphic in one population and monomorphic in another. This system of sexual polymorphism provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of oxidative stress. One of these is the photochemical oxidation of the pigment molecule, which is a major cause of vision loss. The other is the oxidation of the lipofuscin pigments, which are a consequence of the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are known to be important in redox reactions, are important in the photochemical oxidation of the pigment molecule and in the photodegradation of lipofuscin pigments. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, which is the leading cause of blindness in the Western world. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and their evolution is fundamental to understanding the structure of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not only possible, but also has led to the evolution of specialization on other prey types. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological innovations, and that the evolution of specialization has shaped the structure of present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the hand in the hominin lineage leading to Neandertals.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and thus requires the conversion of serine to glycine. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme that performs this conversion, and have identified a cancer cell-line screen that reveals that this enzyme is a targetable metabolic deficiency of many cancer cells. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of a subset of cancer cells, and have shown that this deficiency can be exploited to treat cancer.

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to compaction of the soil, which is a major threat to soil health and productivity. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, and that the current level of compaction is now at risk of compromising the ecological functioning of the soil. We also show that the total weight of modern farm machinery is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that unconstrained roaming of these giants would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. Our results highlight the need for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits.
